tn.text: Nicodemus comes to see Jesus.
This word is used here to mark a new part of the story and to introduce Nicodemus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
Here "we" is exclusive, referring only to Nicodemus and the other members of the Jewish council.
Jesus and Nicodemus continue talking.
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:01:49|1:51]].
"born from above" or "born of God"
The word "kingdom" is a metaphor for the rule of God. AT: "place where God rules" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: How can a man be born when he is old?
tn.text: Nicodemus used this question to emphasize that this could not happen. AT: "A man certainly cannot be born again when he is old!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: He cannot enter a second time into his mother's womb and be born, can he?
tn.text: Nicodemus also used this question to emphasize his belief that a second birth was impossible. "Certainly, he cannot enter a second time into his mother's womb! (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"again" or "twice"
the part of a woman's body where a baby grows
You can translate this in the same way you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:03:03|3:3]].

tn.ref: born of water and the Spirit
tn.text: There are two possible meanings: 1) "baptized in water and in the Spirit" or 2) "born physically and spiritually" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The word "kingdom" is a metaphor for the rule of God in one's life. AT: "he cannot experience the rule of God in his life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jesus continues speaking to Nicodemus.
"You must be born from above"

tn.ref: The wind blows wherever it wishes
tn.text: In the source language, wind and Spirit are the same word. The speaker here refers to the wind as if it were a person. AT: "The Holy Spirit is like a wind that blows wherever it wants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
This question adds emphasis to the statement. AT: "This cannot be!" or "This is not able to happen!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Are you a teacher of Israel, and yet you do not understand these things?
tn.text: This question adds emphasis to the statement. AT: "You are a teacher of Israel, so I am surprised you do not understand these things!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:01:49|1:51]].
When Jesus said "we," he was not including Nicodemus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Jesus continues responding to Nicodemus.

tn.ref: how will you believe if I tell you about heavenly things?
tn.text: This question emphasizes the disbelief of Nicodemus. AT: "You certainly will not believe if I tell you about heavenly things!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: how will you believe if I tell you
tn.text: In both places "you" is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
spiritual things
This means the place where God lives.

tn.ref: Just as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of Man be lifted up
tn.text: This figure of speech is called a simile. Some people will "lift up" Jesus just as Moses "lifted up" the bronze serpent in the wilderness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The wilderness is a dry, desert place, but here it refers specifically to the place where Moses and the Israelites walked around for forty years.
Here "world" is a metonym that refers to everyone in the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the kind of love that comes from God and is focused on the good of others, even when it does not benefit oneself. God himself is love and is the source of true love.

tn.ref: For God did not send the Son into the world in order to condemn the world, but in order to save the world through him
tn.text: These two clauses mean nearly the same thing, said twice for emphasis, first in the negative and then in the positive. Some languages may indicate emphasis in a different way. AT: God's real reason for sending his Son into the world was to save it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
"punish"
"judged innocent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
This is an important title for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
Jesus finishes responding to Nicodemus.

tn.ref: the light has come into the world
tn.text: The word "light" is a metaphor for God's truth that is revealed in Jesus. The "world" is a metonym for all of the people who live in "the world." AT: the one who is like a light has revealed God's truth to the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy|Metonymy]])
Here "darkness" is a metaphor for the area that has not received the "light" of God's revelation in Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]])

tn.ref: so that his deeds will not be exposed
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form. AT: "so that the light will not show the things he does" or "so that the light does not make clear his deeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
This can be stated in an active form. AT: "people may clearly see his deeds" or "everyone may clearly see the things he does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
This refers to after Jesus had spoken with Nicodemus. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:02:12]].
This word means "springs." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
a village or town next to the Jordan River (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: because there was much water there
tn.text: "because there were many springs in that place"
You can translate this in an active form. AT: "John was baptizing them" or "he was baptizing them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Then there arose a dispute between some of John's disciples and a Jew
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form for clarity. AT: "Then John's disciples and a Jew began to argue" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
a fight using words
In this phrase, "look" is a command meaning "pay attention!" AT: "Look! He is baptizing" or "Look at that! He is baptizing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: A man cannot receive anything unless
tn.text: "Nobody has any power unless"

tn.ref: it has been given to him from heaven
tn.text: Here "heaven" is used as a metonym to refer to God. This can be stated in an active form. AT: "God has given it to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This "You" is plural and refers to all the people John is talking to. AT: "You all" or "All of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]]) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])

tn.ref: I have been sent before him
tn.text: This can be stated in an active form. AT: "God sent me to arrive before him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
John the Baptist continues speaking.

tn.ref: The bride belongs to the bridegroom
tn.text: Here the "bride" and "bridegroom" are metaphors. Jesus is like the "bridegroom" and John is like the friend of the "bridegroom." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: This, then, is my joy made complete
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "So then I rejoice greatly" or "So I rejoice much" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "my" refers to John the Baptist, the one who is speaking.
"He" refers to the bridegroom, Jesus, who will continue to grow in importance.

tn.ref: He who comes from above is above all
tn.text: "He who comes from heaven is more important than anyone"

tn.ref: He who is from the earth is from the earth and speaks about the earth
tn.text: John means that Jesus is greater than he is since Jesus is from heaven, and John was born on the earth. AT: "He who is born in this world is like everyone else who lives in the world and he speaks about what happens in this world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: He who comes from heaven is above all
tn.text: This means the same thing as the first sentence. John repeats this for emphasis.

tn.ref: He testifies about what he has seen and heard
tn.text: John is speaking about Jesus. AT: "The one from heaven tells about what he has seen and heard in heaven."
Here John exaggerates to emphasize that only a few people believe Jesus. AT: "very few people believe him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: He who has received his testimony
tn.text: "Anyone who believes what Jesus says"
"proves" or "agrees"
John the Baptist finishes speaking.

tn.ref: For the one whom God has sent
tn.text: "This Jesus, whom God has sent to represent him"

tn.ref: For he does not give the Spirit by measure
tn.text: "For he is the one to whom God gave all the power of his Spirit"
These are important titles that describe the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This means to be put in his power or control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"A person who believes" or "Anyone who believes"

tn.ref: wrath of God stays on him
tn.text: The abstract noun "wrath" can be translated with the verb "punish." AT: "God will continue to punish him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
